PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Mr Nairn:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take note of the report of the inquiry into the role of the Australian Electoral Commission in conducting industrial elections. I should say that it is not commonly appreciated that not only trade unions but also employer organisations are industrial organisations. The report is as equally relevant to those employer organisations as it is to trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is a very balanced and constructive document. It is really quite astounding that it is a unanimous report in circumstances where there could be thought to have been some controversy. Indeed, there were some questions and answers in the federal parliament indicating that the inquiry may have been in the nature of a witch hunt or a scapegoating exercise. That certainly was not the case. I think it is to the credit of the chairman and members of the committee generally that they were able to come up with very sensible terms of reference and produce such a constructive document.

I also indicate appreciation for the role of Mr David Dick, who was seconded to assist the committee. He really was very talented in his knowledge of the area. As a matter of interest, he prepared one of the best historical analyses I have seen of legislation dealing with elections in industrial organisations. That in itself is very worthwhile reading for anyone who has an interest in the area.

Overall, the report found that the Australian Electoral Commission conducts industrial elections in a very professional and even‐handed manner. That was the evidence from not only trade unions but also employer organisations. I think it could be regarded as quite an endorsement of the work of the Australian Electoral Commission.

There were over 3,500 elections in industrial organisations between 1991 and 1996. Of that number, only 1.5 per cent has resulted in inquiries, and only a fraction of that 1.5 per cent has involved allegations of fraudulent conduct. The sensationalism that we can sometimes read in the media regarding trade union or industrial organisation elections occurs in a very small percentage of organisations.

It has been noted that you can have all the penalties and regimes in the world in legislation, but that does not prevent fraudulent conduct. Fraud occurs anyway. By its nature, it is unlawful conduct. It is very difficult for a legislature to legislate to stamp out fraud. What the legislature can do, of course, is to prescribe penalties for fraudulent conduct and an enforcement regime. In the context of the report, we have recommended some strengthening of penalties and some procedures which we believe will minimise fraud, particularly as it could occur in the electoral process, by cross‐verifying the information on the outside of an envelope, for instance, with the voter roll.

BREAK.PARA: I think it is fair to say that some elements of the media would have liked to have seen a much more controversial, a much more sensational document. They have been sadly let down because it is not that. As I have said, it is an overall endorsement of the role of the Australian Electoral Commission in conducting industrial elections.

Several witnesses place great emphasis on the findings of the Cooke inquiry in Queensland, which was conducted by Marshal Cooke, at the behest of the Queensland government, to inquire into the activities of five Queensland trade unions. People who compare our report to the report of the Cooke inquiry should bear in mind that the Cooke inquiry was established under Queensland legislation to look at five Queensland‐registered trade unions, not federally‐registered organisations. Those five unions were referred to the Cooke inquiry because of some pre-existing controversy regarding their behaviour. So the more dramatic findings of the Cooke inquiry very much have to be seen in that context.

We have the opportunity of reviewing the totality of the operations under the federal act, which is an entirely separate piece of legislation, the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and now the Workplace Relations Act. We were quite satisfied with the generality of how these elections are being conducted. Without exception, every organisation that attended to give evidence—and the peak body, the Australian Council of Trade Unions—was at pains to indicate their preparedness to assist in ensuring and developing a regime that gave the greatest credibility possible to the electoral processes within their organisations. They saw that it was important that the public had faith in their electoral processes. All gave balanced and sensible evidence in terms of taking the issue forward.

In making recommendations which we believe will go some way to strengthening the procedures, we constantly have borne in mind the fundamental principles of freedom of association and the right of industrial organisations to regulate their own affairs. However, in our pluralist system of government, and our system generally, industrial organisations, be they employee organisations or employer organisations, have quite significant power and influence in the political process, the industrial process and these days the social and political debate. In that context, the public has a very substantial interest in ensuring that their affairs are regulated legitimately and transparently. So not only an organisation's individual members but also the public can have faith in the authority of their leadership.

I mentioned earlier that one of the recommendations to come out of the report was standardisation of envelopes to avoid the situation we saw recently where a judge in one Federal Court case had some anxiety that voting papers may have gone astray or may have been filled in on a multiple basis by certain candidates on both sides in the election. We think that regime will substantially remove the possibility of irregularities occurring.

We have also recommended that voting be conducted on the basis of membership cut‐off roles. That is, there should be a cut‐off between 30 and 60 days before the opening of the ballot to ensure that the membership rolls are in order and that all members who are legitimately entitled to participate in the ballot can and those who are not entitled to participate are excluded from the election.

Also, we have recommended the establishment of a menu of model rules for industrial organisations—not in the sense of making those rules mandatory but in the sense of the standard articles of association which are a schedule in the Corporations Law. We believe that having such a menu of model rules will assist both industrial officials and lawyers, for instance, in advising organisations as to establishing a system for elections which as close as possible accords with the law and accords with principles and practices to minimise the occurrence of irregularities.

We have also recommended that, after every election that is conducted, the returning officer provide a report concerning the conduct of the ballot. That report will refer to a number of things including whether there were any rules which gave the returning officer some concern, and a recommendation that they be looked at with a view to amending or clarifying them. The report will also contain advice from the returning officer as to the number of voting papers sent out, the number of voting papers that went astray, and any other difficulties that he may have seen.

We have recommended that there be an obligation imposed on industrial organisations to publish that report and, if they see fit, their response to that report so that their members are aware of just what occurred in the electoral process. We recommend that the filing of that report be the trigger for a three‐month period within which a member must commence an application for an inquiry. We think the current period of 12 months is too long. It can cause administrative uncertainty and dislocation for a member to commence an inquiry right on the death knell of the 12‐month period.

We have also recommended that the returning officer undertake a sample check on membership rolls. We have not prescribed a percentage but have essentially left that to the discretion of the returning officer. We think that is a means by which the returning officer will be able to get a feel as to whether the union's membership roll is in order, bearing in mind that it is common for organisations to have 80,000 or 90,000 members—indeed for there to be substantial organisations with up to 170,000 members. So getting the membership roll in order is a substantial task in itself.

We have recommended that there be consultation between the Australian Electoral Commission and peak industrial organisations, both employee and employer organisations, with a view to developing legislation prohibiting the use of union resources in the conduct of elections. I should say that that is not a phenomenon which we have found to be widespread. Indeed, numerous legal authorities say that trade union officials, or officials of employer organisations, have a fiduciary obligation to their organisations such that they offend those principles if they spend the resources of the organisation on an election campaign. There have been numerous cases establishing that fact.

However, there seems to be a problem in that while a member can under section 209 of the act obtain a remedy against the officers that they perform and observe the rules of the organisation, the section does not seem to go so far as to enable a member to seek recovery of any funds spent inappropriately by an officer. There are also other sections in the act which enable the court to make orders rectifying an invalidity, but there is a substantial question as to whether those sections enable the court to order the refund of moneys misspent for improper purposes. It would be good to work out these issues on the basis of cooperation and come up with a mutually acceptable code.

In conclusion, can I say that the work of the secretariat was very professional and first‐class. I think the approach of all members was balanced and constructive, and the outcome of the report is a great endorsement for the committee system of the parliament.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for your cooperation in assisting me to participate in this discussion on the government response to the report by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with southern Africa. At the outset, can I say that looking at the speakers list today you would think that there was some sort of a double act going on between the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and me. Let me assure you that there is not. Most of the reports or items listed for discussion today and for the speakers list come from work that the committee has been involved in over the last couple of years, be it seminars or reports that we brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular paper is a government response to an inquiry into Australia's relations with southern Africa which was started under the previous Labor government. Indeed, I was chair of that inquiry until the election. And, of course, both the right honourable member for New England and I have a great interest in foreign affairs—hence the number of times we are speaking today.

I was a little disappointed in the government response to the report in that, although they were not outright critical, most of the recommendations were fairly wishy‐washy and they agreed in part or agreed in principle. There were hardly any strong aspects of agreement; in fact, there were actually four items where the government agreed totally with what the committee recommended. One was the recommendation that Australia, as part of its assistance to southern Africa, include training for small and medium business. Well, yes, the government agreed to that. That is good that they agreed to that.

They agreed also that Australia continue to work for a total ban on landmines. Well, yes, of course they agreed with that. We all welcome that. I think it is today in Ottawa that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) is signing that. Just diverting for a moment, I must say that I really support the role of the government in the work that they have done, especially the Minister for Foreign Affairs, on banning landmines.

On the recommendation that Austrade research the potential for niche markets for Australia in SADAC countries, yes, they agreed to that. You could hardly disagree with that. And there was the recommendation that the Commonwealth government be prepared to consider any feasibility study submitted by the Western Australian government and the University of Western Australia and Curtin University on establishing a Centre for African Studies in Western Australia. Of course that was agreed to as well. One is grateful for what the government agreed to, but they were not terribly profound items.

The government said that they did not agree with the recommendation that Austrade participate in the Zimbabwe International Trade Fair in 1997‐98. The government argues that, rather than the broad‐brush approach, they should identify certain areas. They quote a trade mission led by the Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer. Yes, that is important. But I also think participation is important, as was shown recently with participation in the Hamburg fair. The government has changed its mind on that one, and one would like to think it might be able to change its mind on participation at Zimbabwe because there is potential for trade in that part of the world, especially in the mining area. People do not see the potential for trade there but, especially in southern Africa, there is great potential for trade.

Australia is not widely represented in southern Africa. In fact, the only places that we have posts at the moment are South Africa and Zimbabwe—there is a post in Nairobi as well. One of the recommendations we made is that Australia increase its representation in Africa, not necessarily, as I have said in this committee before, by opening full diplomatic missions. There are many more innovative ways that we can go about this, such as sharing posts and not having so much of the paraphernalia that goes with a diplomatic post.

We were strongly of the view that the post in Harare should have extra staff. The government has rejected that. I really cannot see why it has rejected that. Current and past High Commissioners there have had a wide representation role in that area. The current High Commissioner represents Australia to something like seven other African states. Some of those states are quite important and have the potential to be quite important for Australia.

One that we constantly overlook is Namibia. The potential for our relationship with Namibia is great. We are not represented there. Then there is Mozambique. Mozambique has got problems. As I mentioned in my preceding contribution, it is now a member of the Commonwealth. It has always surprised me that we do not have diplomatic representatives in at least those two countries. We also made a recommendation concerning the Organisation of African Unity. Recommendation 4 reads:

that. . . Australia offer encouragement and further practical help to the OAU, if requested, to assist in the development of good governance in Africa, particularly Southern Africa, through exploring alternative conflict resolution strategies.

I have made the point before in this House—and it is not covered by this report because we dealt with only the SADC countries of Southern Africa—that, when we got the reference, there was some debate and pressure on us to have a look at Southern Africa. We felt that Africa was such a wide, diverse continent that it would be impossible to bring down a meaningful report, so we thought we should just look at the Southern African region and that string of countries comprising SADC. Even as many of us suspected, the election took over.

But the Organisation of African Unity has its headquarters in Addis Ababa. We briefly opened a mission in Addis Ababa some years ago and then quickly closed it. I think it was open for about 12 months. A parliamentary delegation went through that country, led by the current High Commissioner to Zimbabwe. The recommendation of that delegation was that we open a mission in Addis Ababa. I led one of the great delegations of the parliament through Africa a couple of years later—well not so much a delegation but some of the reports of the delegation. By the time we got there, the post had been closed and all the furniture and everything had been flogged off to the Canadians.

I thought it was a great tragedy that we did not have a post there, not least because the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity is a listening post. I have said this somewhat ad nauseam, but let me repeat it. Perhaps this will be the last time I use this argument. There was much hand wringing when we failed to gain a position on the UN Security Council. There were all sorts of looking at entrails and going to who voted how. This is a topic of particular interest to me because I will be looking at a few votes myself after sitting down and analysing them. But, nevertheless, there was much analysing of the votes cast—who voted for us and who did not vote for us in that.

BREAK.PARA: I do not believe we got a very good vote in Africa at all, not least because we have not had adequate representation in the posts in Africa. We do not have any representation in francophone Africa and we expect those people to turn up with the vote. Had we maintained a mission in Addis Ababa, it would have at least been a point of contact for many of those francophone countries. I think it would have been to Australia's benefit, but I am not quite sure if it would have changed the result.

Looking at the government response really just reinforces my view that the government does not take Africa terribly seriously. People think that I am just critical of the current government. I do not think that the previous government took it terribly seriously either. For one reason or other, we see our future very much in the Asian region. I agree with that. But what we always tend to do in Australia is to look for one area where we can have influence, or where we see our economic and political future and too often we pass by either our former friends—whether they be the European countries—or the potential for new areas where we can have an influence. Australia, of course, is not a super power. We are a small to middling power, but we can have influence in various regions.

In comparing Australia with Sweden, it always surprises me that Sweden, which has a smaller population than Australia, has much more influence in the international community than Australia has. People take the Swedish view quite seriously. That is for many reasons. But we are too closely aligned with the Americans. We are perceived as always going along with them, and we do not develop what we can in various parts of the world. So I think that the government has missed an opportunity to respond more positively. They have not actually disagreed with much, but they have not agreed with much either. They have agreed in part, or in principle.

I think that our relations with Southern Africa are important. From the comments I have received from some of my friends on the African continent, the report that was brought down was a well received report. But as usual, as governments have done in the past, we will go along not working terribly hard to improve the relationship, not doing anything that may offend the relationship, very much taking it for granted. In the long term, I think Australia is the poorer for that, and in many respects, such as was shown in the vote for the Security Council of the UN, we will pay a price either diplomatically or, indeed, economically.

There are great economic possibilities in Africa. Some of the mining companies are there doing quite well. BHP is there working on the platinum mine—it will be one of the largest in the world. But because we fail to be adequately represented in so many parts of Africa, we have missed the boat in many respects in that area. I commend the report to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick. It is a pleasure to see you there. Let me say that I still worry about the functioning of this Main Committee, and I think today's debate illustrates that. There are about two men and a dog here, and none of the ministers, and none of the departmental officials. We have a series of reports dealing with what I regard as fairly significant public policy issues. While I enjoy the opportunity of being able to talk, which is often denied us in the other chamber, in the function of this committee when we have reports such as the ones we are dealing with today, it is a pity that we cannot make a more meaningful use of the relationship of parliament which is designed to provide ministers in government and members an ongoing contact. I worry that we get ourselves too much involved in the thought that just because we produce reports, they are actually going to have any consequence.

BREAK.PARA: May I say to you now that you are in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, that when you were in your other role talking to the motion, many of your comments echoed my own concerns. It began, of course, with the observation that you made that the Sir Humphrey‐like response of the government to the recommendations of the committee rather suggested that they patted us on the head and said, `Yes. It is very good to consider those issues. We are glad to know that somebody is considering them. But the Treasurer has not given us the money for one reason or another, and we have not been able to proceed to adopt them.'

I know there is only one of these recommendations to which they have specifically said no, but instead of saying yes to the others they have added some sort of qualification to most. As one who is worried about where we go in our relationship with the African continent, I think it is important we are more than half-hearted by saying there are things we can do.

The one recommendation that the government has rejected is recommendation 18, that we participate in the Zimbabwe international trade fair this year and next year. I am not sure where we go with expos and international trade fairs but I must admit I have been involved with a few. We took some pretty brave decisions in the past to become involved in expos, and with some of them we wondered whether we were going to get a particular benefit.

Those of us who visited the Brisbane Expo will know what an extraordinary event it was. In this instance, Zimbabwe is a country which is trying hard to establish its presence and its trade contacts. It seems to me that there are ways by which you can participate without its costing a fortune and yet it can bring reasonable benefits.

Having read the government's reasons, it seems to me that the `no' men of the government are saying, `I'm sorry, we haven't got the dough so let's forget it.' Instead of trying to find ways to do things, they are finding reasons why they cannot be done. Frankly, that is not good enough. The reason the government gives in its October response is a bit trite. It says:
The Australian business community values the participation of Austrade in trade displays in South Africa.
That is what Austrade is for. Austrade has the capacity to muster a number of parties in order that they can collectively make a presentation. Further on the comment is made:
. . . it is noted that the Zimbex Trade Fair in Harare is competing with the Zimbabwe International Trade Fair to become the premium trade display in Zimbabwe.
I do not mind which one we go to but I do think we have to be very precise in working with our business community in trying to promote who we are and where we are.

Keep in mind that the report to which this is a response, Australia's relations with Southern Africa, is a report that is directed to a group of countries where there is the most significant growth in trade in the world. People say, `We have so much trade with South Africa because we have the same economies. Even though politics kept us apart, now that apartheid has ended we are able to trade more freely and liberally and therefore we are in a position to go ahead.' Frankly, there is a lot more to it than that. That is why this report tried to pick up what we see as both a political and a commercial attempt to improve our relationship.

In addressing the report I should again pay credit to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, because it was due to your initiative that the report began under your chairmanship. As one who looked at Africa when the recommendation was made, I too shared some of the cynicism that comes from of the government's response. When you look at the nations of Africa, for years the Europeans dominated them. What happened in Africa was a classic illustration of the aftermath of European colonialism. The Europeans did not have the interests of those countries at heart but rather what could be done to advance the economic interests of the Europeans. It has taken considerable time for these African countries to get to the stage of being able to look more positively to the future.

There were so many countries to look at that we cut it down to the SADC countries. By putting the SADC countries together we were able to focus on the fact that there is, if anything, a remarkable transformation occurring in those countries.

We are now proceeding towards an era when we have a better chance of seeing an advancement in those political qualities to which I referred a while ago—democratic institutions, the advance of human rights, the maintenance of the rule of law and a freedom of press. We also have a reasonable opportunity of advancing our political and economic interests together.

Another recommendation that I feel quite strongly about, and again I share the views of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), concerns our diplomatic representation in Africa. We really are not doing well enough. Kerry Sibraa, the former President of the Senate, is our present ambassador. For all that he comes from the other side of politics from me, I believe he has done an excellent job in representing us at seven posts. It is an extraordinary charge. He represents us to seven countries, all of which are different, most of which are underdeveloped, all of which have political institutions that are fairly fragile and really do need a bit of TLC. He has done a very good job. But having one person in one post—certainly with some professional assistance—means that we are not sufficiently addressing the problems of southern Africa.

Perhaps that goes to the core of my concern about this response. I know that this report does not deal with the structure and management of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade but it seems to me that, if anything, the report reflects that the department does need to be concerned about itself. Perhaps we ought to have an inquiry into the department and see whether or not there are ways by which we could improve its management.

I regard Australia's foreign policy as a very important part of looking at the standards of living of Australians. Our foreign policy is not there to promote Australia in the direct sense—because our foreign relationships involve many other issues—it is there to protect our interests, to advance our interests and to advance our understanding. It is there to help other countries develop to the point where they are not likely to be a security threat, where their economic advancement enables them to be self-sufficient, where they are not going to be continually dependent on overseas aid and where they can make their own contribution towards the stability of the world system. Those are all very grandiose ideas.

The foreign office has progressively changed its priorities—we all accept our priority is for Asia—but, as it has done so, we have reduced significantly our presence in a number of regions of the world, and one of them is southern Africa. I am sorry that, in this response, while the government has given this agreement in principle, it all seems to be predicated on the fact that the money is not there. Therefore, it is not going to be possible to provide the financial resources needed to maintain the level of diplomatic and trade representation in southern Africa that I believe is necessary.

There are ways by which you can get an extension of resources. The department at the moment is looking at one-person posts. I do not like that idea. I think it would be far better to provide at least two people to represent Australian interests—that is, two Australian-based staff in any post. Secondly, we can have a look at ways by which we can share overseas posts, which I know we are now doing with Canada. I have seen the current post in Vietnam which seems to work quite well: there, the Canadians share our post; in other places, I gather we share the Canadian posts.

I am not too sure whether that might be a way that we can work in southern Africa. That does not mean that we subordinate our national interest to Canada or to any other country. But it does mean that, in the one facility, you can provide your own Australian national identity and you can promote your Australian views. I think that is fairly important because there are enormous economic opportunities in southern Africa, and we have very real political interests in southern Africa. I think that we need to have in mind that, just as we look today at the Pacific as the area of growth for all those economic tigers—albeit going through some economic difficulty—the growth in the Indian Ocean region offers the same potential for the future as I believe we have been able to gain from the Pacific over the past two decades. I am sorry that, in this response, the government has perhaps not seen those opportunities that are there.

In this response, while the government accepted a number of recommendations that we have made, they have said they are the subject of the Simons review. We have talked about the Simons review earlier in this chamber today. I hope that, having now pronounced where we are going on the Simons review, they will revisit the recommendations we have made and pick them up and provide the resources necessary. For example, recommendation No. 8 states:

AusAID, in conjunction with Southern African authorities, consider including provision of some legal education and training, and assistance to establish legal resource centres, as part of the official development assistance program.
To that the government said that they agreed with the recommendation in principle, subject to the government's consideration of the Simons review recommendations and funding availability.

The point of that is to try and help those countries to govern themselves, to put in place better democratic institutions and, as I keep on saying, to promote the rule of law and to get over the problems which saw Australian soldiers serving in Somalia. While Somalia is out of the region, the point is that if you can promote these countries to look after themselves, you are going to avoid what, to my mind, is a regrettable alternative to establishing those principles by sending military force—even though in Somalia it was a United Nations peacekeeping force. Essentially, it is far better providing legal resources and aid to help these countries to help themselves than it is to have to send in the Australian Defence Force to do so as part of a peacekeeping mission.

There are a number of these other recommendations. I have mentioned the extent to which I believe we need more diplomatic representation, I have mentioned the degree to which I think there are trade opportunities there that need to be promoted, and I do not think the government has accepted those to a sufficient degree. In all, the problem that I see in this response is that the priority given to southern Africa at this stage is really predicated more on a financial dictate than it is on a foreign policy priority. I think that is regrettable. I think we do have reason to try to find ways by which we can do a lot more than we are to promote our interests with these countries.

The only other recommendation I want to refer to is recommendation No. 24. We recommended that we try to develop, with the South African and Zimbabwe governments, a memorandum of understanding on tourism cooperation. We developed the argument in the report; I will not go back to it now. We have been told that the government agrees to it, but it is not going to be pursued under current circumstances. I think that tourism cooperation is essential if we are going to take advantage of new tourist opportunities in the future. We are, each of us, at one end of the tourist track—southern Africa in the African sense, and Australia in the Pacific sense—and by cooperating in this way, we could advance our own trade and our tourism opportunities.

In all, I found the government's response less than adequate. I am disappointed they have not taken more seriously the recommendations we made in our report on Australia's relations with southern Africa. And where they have responded, they have done so with qualifications. I hope they will revisit our recommendations because I believe they are in Australia's best long‐term interests.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Mr Neville:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on this report by the Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform, I would like to put on the record my appreciation and thanks to the now Minister for Transport and Regional Development—but formerly the chairman of our committee—the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) and also, after the member for Lyne was promoted, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), for the very even‐handed manner in which they have chaired that committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to recognise the very learned contribution made by the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) to the committee's deliberations and to the compiling of this report. Over the last seven years that I have been in this place at a federal level, I have come to realise that what the member for Shortland does not know about transport in this country does not exist.

There are two areas in particular that I would like to comment on today before I finish by remarking on some of the issues also raised by the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) in his dissenting report. I notice that he is listed to speak after me here today.

Determining the Commonwealth's proper role in overseeing and funding the national road system was of course the primary goal of our committee. The message that came through in the majority of the submissions to the committee on this subject was, I believe, a resounding endorsement not only for the Commonwealth playing a role over and above providing road funding to the different levels of government but also that it should be active in pursuing that role.

Time and again, the committee received submissions which made it clear to the majority of members that, as far as the future of the national road system is concerned, it is essential—essential, I stress—that the Commonwealth avoid simply giving money to the states and territories and relinquishing any managerial role.

On the contrary, it is necessary for the Commonwealth to involve itself wherever and whenever practical in the planning and the support of our national road system. As the report makes very clear, the Commonwealth is uniquely placed in Australia's federation to take a national approach to road projects. The roads of national importance in this country deserve to be considered as such at the level of government which concerns itself with all other issues of national significance. That, of course, is our Commonwealth. We cannot rely, and we have too many examples in the past of why we should not rely, simply on the states and territories to rise to the occasion and together maintain and coordinate the roads of national importance in this country. Nor do the states and territories want to assume that role from the Commonwealth.

Let us look at some of the submissions that were put to the inquiry by the state and territory governments. The New South Wales government argued strongly that the Commonwealth should play a major part in implementing a national strategy for the road system. The Queensland government stated that the Commonwealth should set and monitor a number of national road priorities. The Northern Territory government argued that the Commonwealth brought a national perspective to roads and that the state and territory governments, from their positions, could not be expected to consider which roads were of national priority and which were not. The Western Australian government argued that a Commonwealth role in the national road system allowed national benefits to be maximised. The South Australian government stated that the Commonwealth, via its involvement in roads, was able to transcend state and sectional interests in order to achieve national objectives. Both the ACT and the Tasmanian governments argued that the Commonwealth had to continue articulating a national focus for the national highway system. It was only the Victorian government which questioned, in any depth, the role of the Commonwealth outside of providing funding for the national road system.

With almost a complete majority of states and territories making their opinions clear on this matter, and with almost unanimous agreement of the members of the committee—and I am glad the member for Parramatta is here because he was the one who put in the dissenting report—I think this report has quite correctly found that the Commonwealth has a considerable role to play in a number of key areas. They are the strategic planning of roads, the setting of national road standards, project approval for roads of national importance and taking responsibility for the overall network of the national road system.

There is a case to be made for a more precise delineation of responsibilities between the different levels of government where roads are concerned. There is a case for getting rid of the duplication and the overlapping of services that do occur between the different levels of government. However, delineation of responsibilities between the different levels does not, and should not, mean devolution of the Commonwealth's responsibilities either to the states and territories or to local government. This is a point I will return to in a moment.

The other aspect of this report that I would like to comment on more closely relates to Commonwealth funding and, in particular, the issue of tied grants. I was glad to see the committee give its approval for tied Commonwealth grants to the states as the best and most effective way of providing a fair and coordinated national approach to funding our road system. I join the honourable member for Shortland in stating for the record that I too viewed with reluctance the abolition of tied grants by the former Labor government in 1991. I considered it a mistake at the time and, six years later, I still think it was a mistake. It is fairly obvious to most of us that it has been exactly that.

BREAK.PARA: Again, the submission from the Victorian government was the only one out of all of those received from the states and territories which expressed dissatisfaction with the idea of tied grants. I think this mainly reflects the isolationist approach to government adopted by the Kennett administration, which considers any guidance coming from the Commonwealth as interference. Yet, as we have seen, without tied grants the Commonwealth—and, remember, this is at a time when the states and the territories are complaining about the lack of certainty they face with the current funding arrangements—finds itself burdened with uncertainty of its own. With untied grants the Commonwealth finds itself giving large chunks of money to state, territory and local governments, without complete confidence that the money is being used for the specific purpose of maintaining and building roads.

If we were to untie all funding, the Commonwealth would need to be assured in some way that the money it was allocating to the states and the territories was being used for the express purpose for which it was intended. In its submission to the committee, the New South Wales government stated:

If Commonwealth funding was to be untied, an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States and the Territories would be essential to demonstrate what it is trying to achieve, with an agreed target nationally through strategic plans.
Considerable debate would be required to work out equitable, acceptable criteria for allocating payments to the States and Territories.

Coming to such an arrangement would be fraught with difficulties. It would require a great deal of trust and goodwill on both sides. If we are being completely honest, that may be the most difficult thing of all. Ultimately, it does not match the benefits associated with a well articulated system of tied grants.

The committee has also taken on board the criticism contained in a number of submissions regarding the level of uncertainty which currently exists for the states, the territories and local government in respect of the Commonwealth's funding arrangements. There was an undeniable concern among the submissions over the unpredictability of Commonwealth funding and the problems that such instability brings.

I warmly support the committee's recommendations that the Commonwealth attach greater certainty to its funding of roads by implementing a guaranteed funding approach for a rolling three‐year period. It was not a surprise to any of us to see the Treasury mandarins cautioning us against recommending such a move and advising us that it would inhibit the Commonwealth's need for budgetary flexibility. While we took such advice on board, I was happy to see the argument for increased certainty and efficiency in road funding won the day.

Finally, I would like to turn to the dissenting report of the member for Parramatta. In reading the member for Parramatta's report—and having listened with interest to his short speech in the House on the report in November—I believe his difficulty with the committee majority report seems to be one of ideology, of philosophy and of his understanding of what constitutes the proper relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. I fear, however, that the member for Parramatta has let ideology and philosophy blind him to the realities of what makes good sense for the road system in this country. I personally find it difficult to comprehend that the member for Parramatta could sit through all of those public hearings, read all of the submissions, which were handed into the committee, and yet come to the conclusion, as he did in the House the other day, that the Commonwealth has `no business in roads'.

The member for Parramatta wants to devolve the Commonwealth's powers back to the states, beginning with the national road system. Yet, apart from the submission from the Victorian government, that is the last thing on the minds of the other seven states and territories. As the committee was guided by these submissions, as much as anyone else, perhaps the member for Parramatta would do better to lobby the governments in those other states and territories to get them to change their minds. He would then have a better chance of convincing the committee of his argument.

I know the member for Parramatta likes to use a famous quote or two or three to illustrate his point. After reading his dissenting report, I had begun to think he had swallowed a book of familiar quotations before putting pen to paper. He was certainly still digesting them when he spoke on the report in the House. With this in mind, I am sure he would appreciate this bastardisation of a quote from Shakespeare: `There are more things in heaven and earth, member for Parramatta, than are dreamt of in your philosophy.' That includes, mundanely enough, the maintenance of planning of the national road system in this country.

By all means let us clarify the role of the Commonwealth in funding, planning and maintaining roads in this country. But do not let us make the enormous error of getting rid of its guiding influence and the perspective it can offer outside of the simple allocation of funds. Let us not let ideology and philosophy blind us into going down that path.

In conclusion, along with my fellow members, I would like to again thank the chair of the committee and the member for Shortland for their work and to thank the standing committee staff for their ceaseless devotion to duty. I would like to put on record that the secretary was Meg Crooks, the inquiry officer was Geoff Johnston and the research officers were Jason Allford and Maria Grainger. The administrative officers, Annette Fischer, Natalie Milner and Lena Ridley, certainly did more than what was called for them to do.

What is showing very clearly with some of the committees we seem to be sitting on now in the House is that when we amalgamate a number of portfolios into one committee, if we are going to carry that type of load, and we as members are expected to, well and good, but, more appropriately, we should be looking at a greater staffing level. I do not think in future we can expect staff, no matter how good they are—and the staff on this particular committee were second to none—to carry the loads that they had to over the recent reports that we have completed. Again, I commend them, and I also thank fellow members.

We certainly took evidence that was varied. We certainly took opinions on board that were varied. I believe this report in its totality is a very good report. It is a report that is worthy of an answer—a very quick answer—from the government. I commend the report to the House and I will be looking forward to the minister's reply, bearing in mind that for possibly 90 per cent of the evidence that we took and the submissions to this inquiry he was chairing the inquiry. It certainly will make some interesting reading when the government finally tables the response to this report in the House. I commend the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the contribution of the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). She highlights the gravity with which one ought to approach the issue of a dissent, particularly as a government member of a committee with a government majority. The member for Prospect speaks as arguably one of the most experienced public figures in Australia, having served as mayor of her local community, as a member of the state parliament, as a minister of the Crown in the New South Wales government and now as a senior figure in the Labor opposition. So I take her views with considerable regard and respect. I nonetheless find myself in dissent.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the member for Prospect is not alone but that, in fact, I am alone on this issue. Of the 14 members of the committee, 13 found themselves in clear agreement on the basic principles and findings of the report. I stand as something of a shag on a rock, a voice in the wilderness; nonetheless, I stand firmly in dissent on two key issues of the report.

The first is the question, as the member for Prospect said, of what is the appropriate constitutional relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. The second is the question of the role of private investment in the road network. They were the two principal issues on which I found myself in disagreement. Were one to accept that the status quo in terms of Commonwealth‐state financial relations is acceptable, then there is much in the report about which I could agree and with which I could concur. But starting as I do from that fundamental philosophical or, if you like, ideological point of difference, I find myself in dissent.

I want to address firstly that question of Commonwealth‐state financial relations and to turn later on to the question of private investment in the road network. My feelings and instincts on the subject come in part from my experience serving as a staffer to two ministers in the New South Wales government—one a minister for minerals and energy and the other a minister for roads and transport—in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Over that period, I formed a view about the role of the Commonwealth in what I regarded as more naturally or appropriately state government affairs.

It did seem to me that the Commonwealth was remote from those who actually deliver services, remote from the coalface of service provision and decision making. It seemed to me that the Commonwealth frequently acted as a kind of constitutional bully, using its financial power and the lopsidedness of the Commonwealth‐state financial relationship to force policy outcomes on the states which it seemed to me were well beyond the constitutional warrant of the Commonwealth. I refer back to what I see as the seminal point in this debate, and a key point in understanding public policy in this country, which actually relates to the Federal Aid Roads Act 1926.

With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, I quote for the first time, in either this chamber or the other, James Scullin, the then leader of the ALP opposition in the government of Bruce. This is his response to the then transport minister's second reading speech on the introduction of the Federal Aid Roads Act. Scullin rose and said:

I have not the slightest objection to this Parliament making a grant or a gift to assist the State Governments in any direction it considers necessary; but there is a marked distinction between a gift to the States . . . from an overflowing Treasury, to assist them in developmental work, whether it be for road‐making or railway construction, and introducing a permanent and continuous policy over a period of ten years.

Honourable members can draw a distinction between the gift of a sum of money for constructing a few main roads—which is a state function—and introducing a policy under which new taxation is to be imposed in order to enter the field of road construction in state territories. We are exceeding our constitutional rights when we invade, in this way, territory under the control of state authorities, and that, in my judgment, is the fundamental objection to the bill.

My argument is that nothing fundamental has changed in those 71 years, that exactly the same arguments that were being had in the chamber on the day that the Federal Aid Roads Act was introduced are relevant today, and I will seek to substantiate that in my remarks in a few moments. Before doing so, I quote another paragraph from Scullin's response to the Federal Aid Roads Act. This has got to do with the nature of federalism and the federal compact which governs the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. Scullin says:
The supporters of the Government are continually chiding the Opposition—
that is, the Labor opposition—

for being unificationists. It is true that we favour one sovereign government for Australia, but we are, at least, honest enough to say that, whilst we have a Federal system, it should be respected, and that we should not try to undermine it. It is the duty of the Government and those who stand for federation . . . not to undermine it, and those who believe in changing it in a constitutional way should also respect the union until they can openly bring about a unified system such as they believe in.

The practical consequence of this lopsided relationship, of the abuse of power by the Commonwealth, the breach of the spirit of the constitution, is that Australia now practises, in the words of Denis James from the Parliamentary Research Service, `the highest level of vertical fiscal imbalance of any federation in the world.' I just want to repeat that: `Australia practises', in the words of Denis James, `the highest level of vertical fiscal imbalance of any federation in the world.'

In my dissenting report, I cite the fact that, in 1996‐97, the Commonwealth raised $130.7 billion in revenue. On the other hand, Commonwealth outlays for its own purposes were only 58 per cent of total generated government outlays. As a result, in the same year the Commonwealth provided the states with grants amounting to $34.6 billion. Overall, in 1995‐96, Commonwealth assistance comprised 45.8 per cent of state and territory revenues.

What we have done is not only usurped more and more state functions, as Scullin so clearly elucidated, but also deprived the states of the capacity to raise their own revenues. We then get into this terrible situation where, every time you have a premiers conference or a council of Australian governments, you get this name calling and you get this refusal of anyone to accept responsibility. The buck stops nowhere because the states blame the Commonwealth for a lack of funds and the Commonwealth blames the states for failing to discharge their constitutional duties—

TALK.START.PARA: —And local government blames everyone.

—And local government blames everyone. I am arguing for a fundamental re‐engineering of Commonwealth‐state financial relations to avoid the bureaucratic duplication, the cost shifting and the lie which is really at the heart of public life in Australia as a result of this fundamental breach of Commonwealth‐state power and financial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Aid Roads Act subsequently became the subject of curial consideration in the State of Victoria v. the Commonwealth 1926 roads case in which the High Court rejected Scullin's argument and upheld the act introduced by the government of Stanley Melbourne Bruce, and you saw this massive increase in the scope of Commonwealth power because of its capacity to manipulate section 96 grants to go into any area of state policy that any particular Commonwealth minister, on any whim of the day, decided he wanted to enter into.

That has been very destructive for our relations. I believe we have to have one thing or the other. As Scullin says, if we want to have a unification, a unitary system of government where there is just the Commonwealth and local government, let us put it to the people and ask them. But let us not do it by stealth, because the abuses of public administration which flow from that stealth are many and varied.

BREAK.PARA: I want to turn now to the issue of private investment in the road network. In particular, my dissent flows from a conclusion of the majority report which says:
BOOT schemes—
or build, own, operate, transfer schemes—

are unlikely to be the best method of delivering Commonwealth road projects . . . The Committee also considers that BOOT schemes are unlikely to be the best method of delivering State/Territory and local road projects.

That second recommendation from our committee deliberations is a breach of the basic convention that the Commonwealth does not venture into the field of state exclusive responsibility and lecture on or dictate to the states what is good for them. We restrict ourselves in our inquiries to recommendations over which the Commonwealth has direct responsibility, but in this instance we have decided to draw a very long bow, to enter—in an excessive way, in my view—into the field of the states and to start directing policy. Furthermore, in my opinion we have done it on the basis of evidence before the committee which was either incomplete or inaccurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's when you should have questioned it.

—That is right—and I have questioned it at various points through the hearings of the committee. The basic view of the committee was that there is not a real transfer of risk to the private sector. We are talking about these urban motorways or tollways. The view of the committee was that there was not a bona fide transfer of risk from the government to the private sector, that the private sector was deriving a benefit from these roads which was not matched by the commercial risk of delivering the project.

BREAK.PARA: That is not a view that I adhere to or uphold, and so I was at pains in the minority report to demonstrate the evolution of risk transfer over these projects, particularly in New South Wales, beginning with the Sydney Harbour Tunnel and moving through the M5 motorway, the M4 motorway, the M5 extension and, most recently, the M2 motorway. We have seen the evolution in sophistication of both government and the private sector in managing the risks associated with these major projects.

If you take, for example, the M2 motorway, which borders the northern boundary of my electorate, that motorway is giving back to 45,000 people every day 40 minutes of their time in going to and from the city—20 minutes in the morning and 20 minutes in the evening for a toll of $2.50 each way. Effectively, that means 20,000 fathers who did not get to do so before the building of the motorway get to have breakfast with their kids before they leave home. In terms of productivity in the economy, this means that you have made a major contribution to the quality of life if you can give people an additional 40 minutes a day disposable time. I reckon you would have to go far and wide to point to any government policy which could match that in terms of the impact on the quality of life of a family.

What you saw there was a group of people gathered together around a $660 million project. You had the bankers providing debt, you had the equity providers investing, you had the insurers, you had the construction joint venturer and you had all of their lawyers gathered together around one table wrestling this beast to the ground. The critical thing about the bankability of one of these projects is that it is subject to market disciplines.

As I mentioned, I worked for the New South Wales Minister for Minerals and Energy. In New South Wales, we created $10 billion worth of excess power generation capacity under the former Electricity Commission because the decisions of that government agency were not subject to the test of whether the community actually needed the infrastructure.

On the M2 motorway the deal would not get done until those bankers are prepared to sign on the bottom line and say, `We believe that over 40 years we will get our money back.' That commercial interest serves a critical public policy interest, which is that we build only the infrastructure that the community actually needs. It helps to ensure that the investment of funds is not subject to political whims and political opportunism.

The problem with the Commonwealth involvement in the national highway is that it has an intrinsic bias against urban roads. All of the studies before the committee showed that the critical need was for investment in urban arterial roads. The member for Prospect and I have both been strong advocates in respect of, for example, the need for the upgrade of the Cumberland Highway in western Sydney and likewise the need for the upgrade of the Sydney orbital route. Yet money is being spent—because of the political pressure, essentially—on a national highway system which is overwhelmingly a rural system, skewing resources away from the real need in urban areas into rural areas. That is because of the Commonwealth involvement in roads policy and roads funding. If we just got out of it and vacated it—

TALK.START.PARA: —We could call them RONPIs and not RONIs—roads of National Party importance.

—Exactly. I accept the interjection of the member for Prospect concerning the politicisation of these resources. I am in serious dissent, and I urge the House to consider the arguments of the dissent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the majority—as everyone else was apart from the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron)—I support the majority recommendations in the report of the Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform on its review of federal road funding. If time allows I will talk a little about some of those recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the spirited speech of the member for Parramatta, however, I would like to deal with the minority report and to put a counter view of the issues that he has raised. He argues that the Commonwealth should get out of direct funding for roads and hand the money over to the states for them to expend, firstly because of vertical fiscal imbalance and also because he thinks funds are being wasted on the national highway which would be better spent on urban roads.

The term `vertical fiscal imbalance' means that the Commonwealth raises a lot more money than it spends for its own purposes—and the states correspondingly, through their revenue raising activities, raise a lot less money than they need for their own expenditures. The Commonwealth makes payments to the states to enable them to make up the deficiency, but this leads to a very substantial imbalance between revenues raised and expenditures by the states and the Commonwealth. This situation is called vertical fiscal imbalance.

Whatever one thinks of that—and it seems to me that there are certainly strong arguments for some correction of it—it seems to me strange that the member for Parramatta, in his minority report, is arguing to make it worse. What he is arguing is that the Commonwealth should get out of direct road funding, making own expenditures on roads, and make more payments to the states. This would mean that the states would have more expenditures of their own, and even greater imbalance between the revenues they raise and their own expenditures. The Commonwealth likewise would have an even greater imbalance between the revenues it raises and its own expenditure.

Vertical fiscal imbalance would be made worse by the proposal of the member for Parramatta, who uses vertical fiscal imbalance as an argument that we should not be funding roads directly at the Commonwealth level. It is just a total non sequitur.

Also, if the Commonwealth is to get out of direct road funding and hand the money to the states, why stop at roads? This is an argument to end Commonwealth funding for education, for health, for housing, for community services, for a whole host of expenditures that the Commonwealth is involved in, and an end, therefore, to a national approach to expenditures in all those areas. It means that we would not have a capacity for a national education system; we would not have standards being set for national health; and, likewise, we would not have a national road system.

The reason that we fund a national highway is that, if we left it to the states, we would probably have extremely inadequate links both between our capital cities and for the nation as a whole in terms of its national road system. That, it seems to me, would be a great deficiency in terms of our unity as a nation. It would reduce the economic efficiency of interstate transfers which take place through roads; and, of course, it is very important to us that those transfers are as efficient as possible. We would not have a highly efficient system to anything like the degree which we have at the present time, if we were to rely on the states to build it, because the concentration of the states would be more likely to be on areas which they saw as being to their own maximum advantage, without looking at the national overall benefit. I reject absolutely the view of the member for Parramatta in his approach, which is one of absolute states rights extremism.

The argument that funds are being wasted on the national highway and would be better spent on urban roads misses the point that we have in fact, in recent years, moved to have included in the national highway system the urban ring roads which link the national highway into and out of capital cities. This has already been funded in Melbourne with the western ring road; $600 million of federal government money has been put into the western ring road, thus linking the national highway and bringing about a tremendous economic boost to the western region of Melbourne as well as a greatly facilitated flow for interstate transport around the city of Melbourne—and for intrastate transport, for that matter, as well. Thus, we already have that example of a great urban benefit coming from federal government funding of the ring roads.

The New South Wales Road Traffic Authority says the number one road of importance in New South Wales is the similar ring road in Sydney, linking the national highway coming in at Liverpool and coming in at Hornsby. That orbital road, which the member for Parramatta referred to, is a most important road, and that will presumably be funded under the national highway program, following upon the completion of the western ring road; and the same thing can also be done to enhance the ring road system in Brisbane. Thus, we do have an added concentration of national highway programs on the urban road system in recent times, and I think the point being raised by the member for Parramatta is quite wrong.

In relation to the minority report, of course, there is the important area regarding BOOT projects, which the member for Parramatta contends that the majority was wrong on, because it said that they were unlikely to be the best method of delivering roads at the Commonwealth, state or local government level in the future. And his report cites 10 criticisms, in the majority report, of BOOT schemes. The principal one of these is the inadequacy of the risk burden carried by the private sector operator, and the corresponding and inappropriate level of risk borne by the government—and, therefore, the taxpayer—for roads that they are supposed not to own.

In this matter, the minority report relies heavily on a response by the New South Wales Road Traffic Authority to very strong criticisms by the New South Wales Auditor‐General of the Sydney Harbour tunnel project and the Sydney M4 and M5 toll roads. The minority report accuses the majority report of ignoring the RTA response to the Auditor‐General, and proceeds to rely very heavily on the RTA response by quoting slabs of it in criticism of the Auditor‐General in his report. Indeed, the minority report reads very much like a whole lot of special pleading by the RTA.

However, the minority report entirely ignores the Auditor‐General's rejection of the RTA response. The fact is, despite the RTA's strenuous objection, the Auditor‐General strongly maintained his original position. For example, in relation to the Sydney Harbour tunnel, the Auditor‐General commented on the RTA response to his report. I refer to the publication Private participation in the provision of public infrastructure: the Roads and Traffic Authority and the foreword to that by the Auditor‐General, in which he said:

The Authority asserts that only the Auditor‐General believes that the risks of ownership reside with the Authority . . . This statement ignores that its accounting adviser can also see reasons why it would be acceptable for the Authority to recognise its ownership of the Tunnel. It ignores Westpac's view that the Government and the Authority have the financial risks. It ignores that the Sydney Harbour Tunnel Company has no continuing benefit or risks from its legal ownership. And it ignores the Public Accounts Committee of the Parliament of New South Wales' view that the Authority is the carrier of Tunnel risks.
Perhaps the Authority is the only entity that cannot or will not see that it is the risk taker.
That was the Auditor‐General's comment on the proposition by the RTA that it was not the risk taker in regard to that project. Also, he went on to say in relation to the RTA:

Indeed, if I could be mildly critical of the authority, now up to its eighth legal action concerning the report, I could not agree that it cooperated with this audit. In fact, its approach could hardly have been more uncooperative. If the Roads and Traffic Authority has in the community a poor reputation for objectivity and responsiveness, its approach to this report reflects that.

I do not think there was much acceptance by the Auditor‐General of any of the RTA's comments. He regarded it as a pretty maverick outfit. Nor has there been a marked change in the Auditor‐General's approach in subsequent reports of this kind.

The minority report endeavoured to argue that there had been an improvement in the allocation of risk in the later road projects. It quotes the New South Wales Auditor‐General on page 134 of the report as saying:

The report on the M2 motorway published at the beginning of 1995 noted the improvement (building on experience from previous schemes) in the balance of risks to be borne by the developer and the RTA, in particular, contractual arrangements . . .
Then there is a break and it goes on:
The arrangements proposed for the contract for the Eastern Distributor continue the improvement in the balance of risks observed in the report on the M2.

In other words, it is arguing that the Auditor‐General was saying there was this improvement. What it left out, however, was significant because what it left out were the comments by the Auditor‐General to this effect, and this was in the break in those quotes:

BREAK.PARA: However, it also highlighted the uncertainty that remained over the underlying costs and benefits of such schemes for the state and for the transport network as a whole. While recognising some of the benefits from private sector financing and operation of some schemes in terms of efficiency, timing and risk sharing, it suggested that public ownership of such schemes might offer the potential for better management of traffic risk over the road network as a whole, more efficient pricing mechanisms and a more optimum public transport network.
It concluded:

This audit cannot definitively answer whether, from a financial viewpoint, private ownership of the M2 is the state's interest. It suggests that it need not be in the state's interest and it recommends that the government, with respect to future projects, carefully examine the relative economic benefits of private vs public ownership of urban tollways (and the effects of different revenue raising mechanisms).

All of that absolutely crucial reference to the fact that what he was really saying was that there was no evidence to show that private sector was better than public sector, and listing a stream of benefits for public sector over private sector was left out of that quote to try to suggest that the whole thing was moving in a way which was much more acceptable to the Auditor‐General. That is just a misquoting of what the Auditor‐General was on about.

Also, this misuse of quotes is also displayed in regard to the EPAC report on private infrastructure which is mentioned on page 139 of the minority report. In that respect, there is a reference to the EPAC report talking about BOOT‐type schemes and some advantages from those. What it leaves out are comments by the New South Wales Auditor‐General in his review of the eastern distributor road and this is not mentioned at all in the minority report. In respect of that EPAC task force, it concluded:

In the broad, BOOT‐type structures are likely to be least advantageous for urban roads. In reaching this conclusion, it considered that the incremental efficiencies from private ownership are likely to be smaller in roads than in other sectors and the private financing cost penalty more pronounced owing to greater network risk and higher transaction costs.

It is quite clear that the reference to EPAC that is supportive for the minority report position is quite wrong. The EPAC position was quite against the use of BOOT‐type projects for urban roads. In regard to the eastern distributor, the Auditor‐General showed in the eastern distributor performance audit that he is still very unconvinced about private sector BOOT financing for urban roads, as that EPAC quote shows.

In regard to private financing, it may lead to a lower level of traffic than could be achieved with road tolling, if the providers had access to public borrowing. This was a view put in the Eastern Distributor report by the Auditor‐General. The overall benefits of the scheme are reduced because of less traffic using new roads than if they were directly provided by the government. This point was made by Professor Quiggin to the committee also.

Overall, the Auditor‐General calls for a major examination in regard to financing urban motorways. On page 2 on the eastern distributor report, the Auditor‐General of New South Wales in mid‐1997 says:
The evidence that urban toll roads are not as effective as other options is very strong.
He goes on with some other stuff that I do not have time to quote, talking about some advantages of government over private sector roads.

It is clear from all of that that the committee was on the right track in pursuing its approach to BOOT‐type schemes. It did not rule them out. It said that they should be looked at on a case‐by‐case basis and that there should be a clear benefit over costs associated with such projects before one pursued that kind of financing.

That is what the Auditor‐General keeps saying in New South Wales. That is what he keeps saying has not been happening. That is why he keeps saying that the New South Wales government approach to this has not been correct under either government, and that we need to be terribly careful about going down the path of BOOT‐type schemes unless we are absolutely sure of getting a good return on our money. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be associated with this discussion of a report. I am equally very pleased to be associated with Planning not patching: an inquiry into Federal road funding . It was an extensive inquiry, with 800 or more exhibits and submissions put to the committee, quite a number of public inquiries and a lot of research work.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to record my appreciation of the professionalism, good conduct and good grace of the committee secretariat involved with the standing committee behind this report. I direct this especially to Meg Crooks, the committee secretary; Geoff Johnston, the inquiry officer; the research officers, Jason Allford and Maria Grainger; and the administrative officers, Annette Fischer, Natalie Milner and Lena Ridley. They managed to sort a way through the various bits and pieces of chaff which came before the committee and helped us to understand better some of the technical aspects we need to understand in the compilation of reports such as this.

Having said that, let me say I think the best part about this report is that it reasserts the importance of the role of a federal government in the question of proper planning for road infrastructure in this country. Many times since coming to this place, I have said that ever since 1788 government has had an absolute role in ensuring that the proper infrastructure all citizens need is available. In a country where the population is sparse and the distances are great, it is a valid and legitimate role of government to provide infrastructure, so that citizens can go about their pleasure and their business, and good results are there for the community as a whole.

There are obviously great defence implications in ensuring transport infrastructure, such as roads, are well thought out. The best part of this report is that it really does reassert the importance of the role of the federal government in ensuring national outcomes from road infrastructure.

It points out clearly that states can become very inward looking and parochial. This is fair enough from a state's perspective. But we find mismatching of the quality of infrastructure on either side of state borders because a road in is not as important as a road out.

The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) is sitting in the chamber here as one of the government whips. I know for certain that he is very frustrated in trying to convince the New South Wales state government Road Transport Authority to do the right thing as far as getting the national outcome that people in my electorate certainly want is concerned—that is, making sure that the Pacific Highway through his electorate is upgraded completely in keeping with this government's plans. It is frustrating to think that a state government may flick certain financial considerations away from achieving the good national outcome.

I certainly know that because my electorate is only about 100 kilometres away from the electorate of the honourable member for Richmond. In suburban Brisbane we look with a great deal of interest to the progress along the Pacific Highway as it traverses New South Wales. So Queenslanders have a great deal of concern if the New South Wales government is not doing the right thing as far as the Pacific Highway is concerned. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, as the Pacific Highway travels through your electorate, you will be keeping a close eye on the progress of the upgrade.

As an aside, I think that one of the most interesting comments to come from New South Wales witnesses when they came to the hearing was a suggestion that perhaps all of Victoria's road funding allocation should be sent to New South Wales for a year so that they could finish off the Hume Highway. It would be the best thing for Victoria if the New South Wales government were able to complete the duplication of the Hume Highway. South of the Victorian border you have a magnificent road, but after crossing the Victorian‐New South Wales border, and in and around Canberra, Goulburn and Yass, the roads are not as good as they should and could be.

So here we have state authorities not looking at the national imperative from a New South Wales perspective. Perhaps it is a Sydney‐centric look, or, from a Victorian perspective, a Melbourne‐centric view. I know that in Queensland it is not quite the case because it is a very decentralised state by nature. What a lot of these different state road planning authorities are missing is the fact that there is a national interest in completing the Hume Highway in duplication, and in completing the Pacific Highway duplication between Sydney and Brisbane. Likewise, there is a national interest in continuing to upgrade the northern reaches of the Bruce Highway from Port Douglas and Cairns through to Mackay where much of that road leaves a lot to be desired.

It is important that the federal government places national considerations in the execution of road construction in this country. It has never been a constitutional right of the federal government to control the construction of roads. It is something we inherited because, after all—

TALK.START.PARA: —We stole it.
