—As the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) said, we have more money generated from a taxation revenue point of view than we actually spend. The vertical fiscal imbalance gives us a great deal of control over the expenditure of moneys in a number of different areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) might suggest that we have stolen that right from the states but, in fact, it is quite right and quite proper, and in general conversation there is no argument about the importance of the federal government looking at things in a national perspective when it allocates funds to the various states. So this inherited role is endorsed by the majority report of the standing committee.

It is important, I think—and I totally agree with the findings of the committee—to tie the grants for road purposes very specifically to the states because it was mentioned to us in a number of asides that some darned good swimming pools were built instead of roads. In other words, money went off into different areas but it ended up being used for other purposes. I do not believe this is in the national interest at all. Because of the importance of road infrastructure, it is vital that, if we are going to allocate funds for roads, roads are built—and not only that: that they are built with the proper consideration.

Another important aspect of the report was contained in recommendations 13 and 21 which talk about national highway links and arterial roads. In the case of my electorate of Moreton, there certainly is some direct interest in that. I saw first‐hand, before becoming the member for Moreton, just how poor the planning of the previous Labor government in Queensland had been with regard to an urban national highway link in the form of Kessels Road.

BREAK.PARA: Kessels Road was a fairly quiet suburban road with a couple of lanes—a lane each way. But over the last 15 years it has slowly but surely developed into this national highway link. In fact, the previous Labor government made it part of the national highway system linking Ipswich Road, the Cunningham Highway, the New England Highway connection right through to the Bruce Highway via the Gateway arterial in my electorate. As a result we are now finding interstate transporters thundering down this road, creating a lot of undue hurt, confusion and, perhaps, health problems amongst constituents in my electorate.

A lot of this came about because it was a quick and convenient thing for the state government at the time in Queensland to do. The federal government kicked in the funds to make sure it was possible but, at the end of the day, the previous federal government did not take account of the parochial view of the state government of the day and threw the money at it without any connection.

We are inviting the federal government of today to connect itself with the outcome, and not just simply make the money available without question but call to account the state governments for the conduct of the funds that are put forward. That is what tied funding is all about and I think, for so many reasons, good national outcomes will come as a result of the recommendations that have been put forward by this inquiry.

In closing, can I say that the minority report of the member for Parramatta perhaps was a few years ahead of its time. I am in a very generous mood because it is close to Christmas. But I suspect that one of the important recommendations within the inquiry is where we have said that the whole conduct of road funding, and the conduct of national outcomes, should be reviewed every five years to ensure we are getting the right results. Perhaps in five years time the member for Parramatta will make a submission that is something along the lines of his minority report. I applaud his determination to put his point of view, as he has done so well here today and as he has done in his minority report. I do not have to agree with all the tenets but I absolutely recommend the result of this long inquiry to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur, Stewart, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available, I want to make a few remarks on the report Planning not patching . Firstly, could I commend the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform and its members and secretariat for a very carefully thought through report. Of all the parliamentary reports that I have been associated with in my time in the parliament, I think this one saw the participation of most members of the committee in the detail, in the final recommendations and in the script of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, it is a reference document for the views of people associated with roads and the views in relation to the very difficult problem of allocating resources—federal, state and local. Certainly, the committee took into account all those views around Australia and I think the final report is a monument to those submissions. The distillation of those views comes through in the report in trying to solve what is almost an impossible problem.

I also put on the public record my thanks to the former chairman, now the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), for his contribution as chairman, for the way in which he conducted the inquiry and the fair manner in which he conducted all deliberations. I also thank the members of the opposition, the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis)—both as federal Treasurer and as a member representing Victorian interests—and the deputy chairman, the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), for their contributions and their long experience in this parliament and their long experience in the matter of road funding.

Broadly, the fundamental problem facing the funding of roads in Australia is that about $11 billion is collected and about $6 billion is spent on roads on an annual basis. So there is a legitimate argument by all Australians who drive vehicles that some of that money that has been collected for the purposes of road funding has not been allocated. Inevitably, there will never be enough money for road construction and maintenance. That will be an ongoing argument no matter who is in government; no matter whether they are state, federal or local governments.

Once again, the argument about a national highway system, and the definition of the system, came to prominence in the debate in the committee. At a parochial level, and the member for Gellibrand would understand this, there is an argument that the Geelong to Melbourne road should be part of the national highway system in view of the fact it connects two such important cities. That argument, of course, continues in other parts of the Commonwealth. The definition of a national highway system is something that the committee looked at but had some difficulty in giving it a final recommendation.

Of course, the roads of national importance add another dimension to the possibility of the Commonwealth assisting with other secondary roads that do help in terms of commerce and manufacturing. I think it is clear that the state authorities are the instrumentalities that build, construct and maintain roads. There is always the difficulty of the funding, of the supervision between the Commonwealth and the state authorities, and certainly that came through in the submissions.

I think the committee has made a bold decision in saying that we do not agree with hypothecation. The figures show that in fact it is not being followed. We agreed that hypothecation was not a reality when one looks at the way in which funding is now allocated in Australia.

I make mention of the bridges situation. An interesting aspect of our inquiry related to the allocation of funds needed for the construction of bridges between Victoria and New South Wales. It is something that I think governments have tended to overlook. Both state governments have passed the buck. The federal government has been reluctant to take up that fairly considerable amount of capital expenditure and it is something that I draw to the attention of the chamber.

In terms of private sector involvement, there has been an ongoing debate by those on both sides of the chamber. I have been convinced by the arguments that were put to the committee, although they might not accord with my normal instinct to support the private sector. But from the arguments that were put forward and the very lengthy discussions that took place, having regard to the build, own, operate and transfer type of road construction, there is some merit in the argument put forward in the report that motorists and the people who use these highways should pay for this construction through their taxes and charges in some form or other. Having regard to the toll system, the availability of capital and the element of risk involved in private construction, I think the analysis by the committee is a correct one. On balance, it is hard to develop a case for encouraging the private sector to build, own, operate and transfer some of these bigger operations; in the longer term, they are for the benefit of the community.

BREAK.PARA: I know my good friend the member for Parramatta does not agree with that. But having listened to the evidence, I understand that the private sector was able to mitigate the risk by having an extension of time, thus ensuring that they enjoyed the benefit of a genuine return.

Finally, I refer to some of the country roads in parts of my electorate—and this also relates to roads in the electorates of other members in the chamber. In my electorate of Corangamite, which produces dairy and timber products, they cannot be compared with the western ring road, on any cost‐benefit analysis. In an intellectual and policy sense, it is very difficult to demonstrate that, but obviously in the longer run we must have soundly constructed roads to support our primary, rural and mining industries, which provide the export earnings of Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the report to the parliament. I say again that I think it is a benchmark document which all state governments will read with considerable interest. Let them be assured that it is a document which represents the collective view of the parliament. It is the view of many experienced members of the parliament who have had a long association with road funding, and the dilemmas and problems associated with those allocations.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Main Committee adjourned at 1.04 p.m. to a date to be fixed.
